title: 15 Ways to Help Your Busy Mother Out around the House

steps.title: Help your mom by cleaning up any objects on the floor.
steps.content: Help your mom by cleaning up any objects on the floor. Take a look around your room: are there books, toys, and blankets on the ground? Pick them up and put them in their spots. [2] X Research source If you have a playroom or a family room that’s looking cluttered, do the same thing there as well. Are there any dishes or cups in your room? Help your mom out by taking them to the kitchen to be washed.

steps.title: Choose a specific area for your papers and backpack.
steps.content: Choose a specific area for your papers and backpack. If you normally sprawl your homework papers and textbooks all over your room, make one particular spot where you'll store your homework. This could be a desk, or just a corner of the room to stack your textbooks and put your backpack. [3] X Research source Having a homework spot doesn't just make your room look cleaner, it makes it easier to find what you need to get ready for school in the morning.

steps.title: Keep your room looking great by making your bed look nice.
steps.content: Keep your room looking great by making your bed look nice. After you wake up in the morning, take a few minutes to straighten out your blankets and pillows. Make your bed as neatly as you can to get it ready for you to doze off to sleep in. [4] X Research source If you know your mom is doing laundry later, help her out by taking the sheets off your bed and putting them in the laundry pile. Try to wash your sheets at least once a week to keep them looking and smelling fresh.

steps.title: Grab plates, silverware, and napkins before you sit down to eat.
steps.content: Grab plates, silverware, and napkins before you sit down to eat. Your mom probably worked hard making dinner for you and your family. Help her out by setting the table and making sure everyone has what they need for the meal. [5] X Research source You can also pour cups of water for everyone at the table.

steps.title: Help care for your animals so your mom doesn’t have to.
steps.content: Help care for your animals so your mom doesn’t have to. Does your family have a dog, a cat, a bird, a fish, or any animal that eats? When it’s time to feed them , grab their food and give them the right amount (if you aren’t sure how much, ask your mom). [6] X Research source Make sure they all have water in their dish, and take them on a walk if that’s what they need! You could also play fetch or play with toys inside the house.

steps.title: Grab a watering can and give your thirsty plants a drink.
steps.content: Grab a watering can and give your thirsty plants a drink. If you have any indoor plants, carefully pour some water into the dirt around the base of the plant. If you have outdoor plants or a garden, you can use a hose to spray water directly into the dirt near the plants’ roots. [7] X Research source Outdoor plants usually only need to be watered during the spring and summer. If it’s raining, your plants are being watered for you! Some plants only need a little bit of water. If you aren’t sure whether or not yours need some, ask your mom.

steps.title: When the trash can is full, bring the bag outside.
steps.content: When the trash can is full, bring the bag outside. You might notice that your kitchen or bathroom trash is overflowing with garbage. If that’s the case, pull the sides of the bag up and tie the bag tightly so no trash falls out. Bring the bag outside to the trash bins, then replace the bag with a fresh one. [8] X Research source If you’re old enough to push the large trash bins out to the street, ask your mom when trash day is. Then, the night before, bring the bins out to the street for the garbage trucks to pick up in the morning.

steps.title: Wash, dry, and fold the clothes to help your mom out.
steps.content: Wash, dry , and fold the clothes to help your mom out. Ask your mom which clothes are dirty and if she wants to sort them first. Then, grab a pile and put the clothes into the washer, followed by some laundry detergent. Turn the washer on to start the load , and plan on transferring it to the dryer when it’s done. [9] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry Nonprofit organization dedicated to providing and improving psychiatric care for children and adolescents. Go to source Some clothes are delicate and need to be washed on a special cycle. Ask your mom beforehand if there’s anything you should set aside before putting in the laundry. When the clothes are dry, fold them and sort them into piles based on where they go.

steps.title: Clean the floors in your home to leave them looking spotless.
steps.content: Clean the floors in your home to leave them looking spotless. Check out the floors in your house: are they dirty, hairy, or dusty? If you have carpet, grab the vacuum and vacuum the floors to clean them up. If you have hardwood, tile, or laminate floors, use a broom to sweep up dirt and hair. [10] X Trustworthy Source HealthyChildren.org Health information from the American Academy of Pediatrics. Go to source If your floors are really dirty, you could even mop them for your mom. Ask her where the mop and bucket are, then fill up the bucket with water and whatever cleaning solution your mom usually uses.

steps.title: Prepare an easy meal for yourself that you can eat on your own.
steps.content: Prepare an easy meal for yourself that you can eat on your own. Your parents might cook dinner, but you can take charge of making your own breakfast and lunch every day. It doesn't need to be fancy. If you're not allowed to use the stove, you can use the microwave to make oatmeal , or just eat cold cereal or yogurt. Pack your own lunch by making a sandwich and bringing along some yummy fruit. [11] X Research source Packing your lunch the night before makes the mornings of school easier. If you have siblings, you can trade off whose turn it is to pack lunch or make breakfast for everybody.

steps.title: Ask your parents what you can do to help make a meal.
steps.content: Ask your parents what you can do to help make a meal. Find things that you can do to help with dinner preparation, like washing fruit, making pasta, slicing vegetables, making a salad, or pouring glasses of water for everybody. [12] X Expert Source Wits End Parenting Parenting Specialists Expert Interview. 5 March 2020. If you have siblings, get them in on it by encouraging them to set the table or grab a drink for everyone.

steps.title: Clean up after a big meal to help your mom in the kitchen.
steps.content: Clean up after a big meal to help your mom in the kitchen. After you and your family are done eating, offer to wash the dishes. You can either load them in the dishwasher or wash them by hand . Then, put the clean dishes away in the cupboards to use later on. [13] X Trustworthy Source HealthyChildren.org Health information from the American Academy of Pediatrics. Go to source If you aren’t old enough to do the dishes yet, focus on taking your dinner plate to the kitchen and scraping any food into the garbage or compost.

steps.title: Wipe off surfaces
steps.content: Wipe off surfaces if they look dingy or dusty. Grab a duster or just a wet rag and go over any flat surfaces in your home, like shelves, tables, or bookcases. Focus on areas that aren’t touched a lot, since those tend to accumulate the most dust. [14] X Trustworthy Source HealthyChildren.org Health information from the American Academy of Pediatrics. Go to source Be extra careful if you choose to dust electronics, like the TV or your computer. Always use a clean microfiber towel, and go gently over the screen so you don’t damage it.

steps.title: Mow the grass or weed the garden outside on a nice day.
steps.content: Mow the grass or weed the garden outside on a nice day. During the summer, you can help out your mom and get some fresh air at the same time. Use a lawnmower to mow the grass, or put on some gardening gloves and pull out weeds by hand . If you aren’t sure which plants are supposed to be there and which ones are weeds, ask your mom before you start. [15] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry Nonprofit organization dedicated to providing and improving psychiatric care for children and adolescents. Go to source

steps.title: Your mom probably has plenty of chores in mind for you to do.
steps.content: Your mom probably has plenty of chores in mind for you to do. If you’re super stumped about what might be helpful, just ask! Your mom can tell you exactly what to do and how to do it, and you can ask her any questions if you’re confused. [16] X Expert Source Wits End Parenting Parenting Specialists Expert Interview. 5 March 2020. Your mom will probably really appreciate you wanting to help. Even if she doesn’t have a chore for you right that second, she’ll love knowing that you’re willing to clean up around the house and lighten her load a bit.
